creator: nd@perlig.de
rpluem@apache.org
text:
Thanks for the info. I think having your rewrite rules and possibly a result of
a RewriteLog with RewritelogLevel 9 could be helpful. If you provide a
RewriteLog, please provide it as an attachment. Furthermore you cutted off the
bt so that it cannot be seen from which httpd function the pcre libarary is
being called. So it would be helpful if you can give us the complete result of
"bt full" in this case.
BTW: Are you using worker or prefork MPM.

creator: jorton@redhat.com
text:
A RewriteLog or at very least the entire mod_rewrite configuration being used,
yes.  Did this behaviour only start after you applied the CAN-2005-2491 patch?

creator: mc@nuxit.net
text:
The behaviour started before the applying of the CAN-2005-2491 patch. The patch 
didnt change anything.

I will ask to the customer the permission to copy paste its redirection rules 
and logs

creator: mc@nuxit.net
text:
Here are the rewriting rules :

RewriteEngine On
RewriteRule ^grenier/contacts/question-([0-9]*)
\.html$     /grenier/contacts/question.php?id=$1  [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^grenier/page-([0-9]*)-(.+)*\.html$     /grenier/details.php?
id=$1&arti=$2 [NC,L]
RewriteRule ^grenier/photos-([0-9]*)-(.+)*\.html$     /grenier/photos.php?
id=$1&arti=$2 [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^archives/Fiche-([0-9]*)-(.+)*\.html$     /archives/fiche.php?
id=$1&arti=$2 [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^grenier/rubrique-([a-zA-Z0-9]*)\.html$     /grenier/go.php?
rubr=$1  [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^grenier/rubrique-([a-zA-Z0-9]*)-([0-9]*)
\.html$     /grenier/go.php?rubr=$1&page=$2  [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^rapide/article-([0-9]*)-(.+)*\.html$     /rapide/article.php?
id=$1&arti=$2 [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^rapide/rayon-([a-zA-Z0-9]*)\.html$     /rapide/rayon.php?rubr=$1  
[NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^annonces/([0-9]*)-(.+)*\.html$      /annonces/details.php?
id=$1&titre=$2  [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^Catalogue-page-([0-9]*)\.html$   /index.php?page=$1 [NC] [L]
RewriteRule ^grenier/galerie-([0-9]*)\.html$   /grenier/galerie.php?page=$1 
[NC] [L]

ErrorDocument 401  /erreurs/erreur401.php
ErrorDocument 402  /erreurs/erreur402.php
ErrorDocument 403  /erreurs/erreur403.php
ErrorDocument 404  /erreurs/erreur404.php
ErrorDocument 405  /erreurs/erreur405.php
ErrorDocument 500  /erreurs/erreur500.php

Moreover, I notice that the problem seems to happen only when the requested URL 
contains the '(' character

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
(In reply to comment #7)
> Here are the rewriting rules :

(PLEASE attach the log next time...)
Anyway, here are your CPU consumers:

> RewriteRule ^grenier/page-([0-9]*)-(.+)*\.html$     /grenier/details.php?
[...]

(.+)* is not an infinite loop, but it can take a long, long time (depeding on
the input millions of years ;-). Especially when the input does NOT match.
The plus and the asterisk each try to get the same input and figuring out which
one of them takes which of the nothing they can match takes that long.

> Moreover, I notice that the problem seems to happen only when the requested URL 
> contains the '(' character

According to the backtrace it should also happen if any PHP file is requested.
(instead of .html). In general, any input that doesn't match (the longer the
input the exponential longer it takes to not match it).

There nothing we can do about it here, except suggesting a good book about
regular expressions. Sorry.

creator: mc@nuxit.net
text:
Ok thank you very much and sorry for the heavy copy paste, but how can we deal 
with that (from the hosting provider side, not the developer one) as the 
RLimitCPU does NOT apply to the Apache children themselves ... ? ulimit -t 
maybe ? Can we just kill -9 such a child without consequence for the other 
childs and global apache working ?

creator: rpluem@apache.org
text:
If you cannot prevent users from doing such things with

AllowOverride none

(which will also boost performance, even more as rewriterules in .htaccess files
are known to be inefficient) or at least prevent users to override FileInfo
commands which would deny rewriterules in .htaccess files, then I fear you have
only organizational matters to fix this by
- identifying these users
- warn them
- lock them out if they do not behave well
It should be sufficient to kill the process with a SIGTERM (kill). SIGKILL (kill
-9) does not seem to be needed and should only be tried if a simple kill does
not work. As you are running the prefork MPM no other connections will be harmed
by this in contrast to the worker MPM.
To get back to the original case of your problem: Replacing

(.+)*

with

(.*)

should fix your problem and deliver the same results in terms of matching and
grouping.
The question is if ulimit -t makes sense because it limits not the actual usage
of the CPU but the total number of seconds a process can consume the CPU during
its lifetime. I am not quite sure what happens to the httpd child processes once
this time is used up. I fear this would have even more disturbing consequences
to your server as this could possibly hit other processes that do not misbehave,
but simply consumed the amount of CPU during their lifetime. Of course you can
use MaxRequestsPerChild to reduce this risk.

Yes, I think exactly like you concerning the use of "ulimit -t"

Effectively, SIGTERMing a child seems to be harmless for the other processes. 
So it's possible to do some process auto killer, but such a problem should be 
quite exceptional, and can be manually solved (by identifying and warning the 
user, which is easy)

Thank you all for your time and help.
creator: mc@nuxit.net
